content.description: Protein digestion in humans is primarily carried out by three enzymes. Pepsin is found in the stomach <math alttext="p H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(pH</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>2)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where it aids in the breakdown of large proteins into smaller peptides, while trypsin and chymotrypsin are found in the small intestine <math alttext="p H 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(pH</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>8)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where they aid in the further breakdown of the proteins into amino acids and dipeptides that can be absorbed into the bloodstream. Graph 1 shows the effect of <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the activity levels of the three enzymes.
content.question: Graph 1. Relative activity of pepsin, trypsin, and chymotrypsin at <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></math> 0 through 11 Which of the following best predicts how the structure and function of pepsin will change as it enters the small intestine?

choices.label: Pepsin will not change in shape and will continue to break down proteins in the small intestine.
Pepsin will not change in shape but may not work due to the basic environment of the small intestine.
Pepsin will change in shape because of the basic environment of the small intestine; therefore, its enzymatic activity will decrease.
Pepsin will change in shape because of the presence of trypsin and chymotrypsin in the small intestine, both of which act as competitive inhibitors.

content.answer: Pepsin will change in shape because of the basic environment of the small intestine; therefore, its enzymatic activity will decrease.
